_source.attribution: We want to give a colossal thank you to the following organizations for their help in the success of our project:Thank you to Wisconsin Lutheran College for all of your financial support as well as encouragement, and providing a place for a Christ-centered education!Thank you to the admissions and marketing department for your help with outreach for our summer camp.A special thanks to the Biology department for their resources, lab space, and mentorship.Thank you Genscript for your generous donation towards building parts!A great many thanks to the Center for BioMolecular Modeling at the Milwaukee School of Engineering for spending time with our summer camp students!Thank you to our advisors, Dr. Henkel and Dr. Werner!They both were of great help with their advice and the numerous hours they helped in the laboratory.We appreciate the work of Dr. Balza, a professor at Wisconsin Lutheran College.He volunteered his time to speak with our summer camp students and show them the various coral species we have on campus.
_source.description: 73,467489 [2004].Note: this article was written by last year s WLC iGEM team, we are using it as it still applies to this year s project.According to the Phage Therapy Center, bacteriophage therapy is defined as the therapeutic use of lytic bacteriophages to treat pathogenic bacterial infection. (1) And while this technique was discovered prior to antibiotic treatments, inconsistent results and a lack of understanding caused it to be almost completely overshadowed by antibiotics.As a continuation of the 2015 WLC iGEM team s project, we have taken the idea of phage therapy for treatment of bacterial infection to a new environment: the coral reefs.(1) Finally, while a phages ability to mutate could be seen as a safety threat, it also provides a built-in mechanism to continue to infect bacteria that have adapted a resistance to the original strain.Without zooxanthellae, corals would bleach (lose color) and die due to a lack of adequate nutrient uptake (3).Hard coral species also use the fixed carbon during the production of their Calcium Carbonate skeleton (3).Because of this the coral are, in effect, stripped of their immune defenses, and their nutrient providers.If the S. marcescens infection could be wiped out with bacteriophage therapy (see our teams previous article on phage therapy below), the coral would have the potential for rehabilitation.2 Aug. 2016.Note: this article was written by last year s WLC iGEM team, we are using it as it still applies to this year s project.TolC is a protein comprised of 471 amino acids to compose a homotrimer that forms a tapered hollow cylinder 140Å in length: a 40Å long outer membrane barrel [the channel domain] that anchors a 100Å long helical barrel that projects across the periplasmic space [1].The protein is exported through translocase, such as AcrAB, then through the TolC periplasmic entrance [1].TolCs role in antibiotic efflux is what interests us as a target for fighting multidrug-resistant bacterial infections.The complicated structure of Elkhorn contains many large branches with a full-grown coral reaching up to twelve feet in diameter(1).Part of the reason Elkhorn is such an important component of reef building is its ability to grow very rapidly.But our reefs are threatened now as never before in a myriad of ways, from pollution, dredging and destruction of the physical reef, to disease and an increasingly acidic environment affecting many aspects of our lives and placing the future of our oceans in danger.One such pressing concern for the coastal reefs of the southern United States (such as those located along the Floridian coast) has been a decimation and massive decrease in the populations of the primary reef building coral of these reefs, Acropora palmata, otherwise known as Elkhorn coral.(2) Phage therapy works based on the bacteriophages ability to lyse specific bacteria while not harming eukaryotic cells.The early founders of phage therapy made many mistakes that ultimately led to antibiotic treatments being favored over phage therapy.These numerous traits of our reefs, that affect so many global interactions, highlight just a few of the many benefits coral reefs provide for the earth we live on.(2) The ever increasing issue of antibiotic resistance has led to a phage research revival.The most significant cause of this scarcity, however, is rampant disease, largely caused by the human pathogen Serratia marcescens.Serratia marcescens, a pathogenic species belonging to the family Enterobacteriaceae, is known to infect humans, as well as other animals.The goal being that a phage can be isolated that will bind to the S. marcescens TolC protein.Without the coral reefs and the solid structure they provide, erosion of beaches and shorelines would proceed at significantly higher rates due to the lack of wave dissipation that reefs provide.Without reefs, many larval fish species would lack an environment in which to develop or would lack a vital link (a food source for example) in the food chain they rely upon.(2) The bacteria are able to thrive in a wide variety of environments including soil, water, and the digestive tract of their host.Phage therapy has overcome many of the obstacles that cleared the way for antibiotics to take over, and is now in many ways superior to antibiotics.This way, phages specific to the Serratia tolC gene can be isolated without having to deal with any harmful bacteria in the lab.[4]Gossard, Kimberly A., "Genetic Profiling of the White Pox Disease Coral Pathogen Serratia marcescens from the Florida Keys" (2014).Honors Program Theses.Specifically, the infection of Elkhorn coral by S. marcescens or white pox can be attributed to immense destruction of the coral reefs(4).Elkhorn coral has been subject to infection by S. Marcescens since the first outbreak of white pox in 1996.(4) Also, phages are very specific, making it difficult to kill the correct bacteria with the correct phages using the technology of the time.[1] Falkowski PG, Dubinsky Z, Muscatine L, and James W. Porter: Light and the Bioenergetics of a Symbiotic Coral. BioScience: Vol."Human Pathogen Shown to Cause Disease in the Threatened Eklhorn Coral Acropora Palmata."(1) Modern technology has also allowed for the easy and effective isolation of phages without disrupting their function.(1) Phages have also been identified with coat proteins that are harder for the body to identify as foreign.First, phages can be very specific and can be programmed to target only the virulent bacteria so as to not damage the microbiomes or probiotics.Read on for a more detailed explanation of the premise and goals of this year s project.Elkhorn coral (Acropora palmata) is a vital reef-building coral native to the Caribbean.Finally, the researchers faced the issue of the phages being rapidly eliminated by the body and were unable to prevent it.Due to the overuse of antibiotics, alternative treatments like phage therapy have been sought.There are also small loops present on the sides of TolC that allow for phage binding or colicin attachment.While some at the time believed that they were viruses, many of the studies hinted at phages being an enzyme that was created by the bacteria.(3) The phages create two enzymes, hollins, which perforate the plasma membrane, and lysins, which attack the cell wall.Thanks to scientific advances, many of the original problems have been solved, and phages are now even superior to antibiotics in many ways.Because of the high efficiency of S. marcescens to utilize glycoprotein components in the mucus, it is able to completely outgrow any other bacteria present.(4) The lack of knowledge also led to very inconsistent reports causing Eaton, Bayne, and Jones to write a report which deemed the technique no better than prior treatments.In addition, while the body metabolizes antibiotics, lytic bacteriophages are constantly replicating in the host bacteria and thus grow exponentially in number.Because WLC is a Christian school, we want our projects to always be rooted in our faith, which is why we chose a project involving good stewardship of the Earth and its resources.(5) There is also much less risk of resistant bacteria forming as only the target bacteria will be infected while the others remain untouched.The new surge of research being done on phage therapy continues to reveal exciting new options for the technique.In the lysogenic phase, the viral genome integrates into the bacterial DNA and goes into a hibernation allowing the cell to replicate on its own until it enters the lytic cycle.Paper 5.Importance of Reef Building Coral and Associated SymbiontsThe importance of hard corals to the global ecosystem as we know it cannot be overestimated.(5) The lack of research and understanding also led to impurities being injected into patients, further infecting them, and denaturing the bacteriophages during isolation leaving them inactive.In the lytic cycle, the bacterium is used to create parts of the phage which are then assembled.The phages do this by injecting their DNA into the host.The reasons for the low population in recent years is due to a wide variety of pressures including predation and bleaching.The outer membrane protein common to many gram negative bacteria: TolC (see our teams pervious article on TolC below), can be cloned into a plasmid and function in E. coli.The bacteria can then enter one of two phases, the first of which is the lysogenic phase.& Hughes, C. STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION OF TOLC: The Bacterial Exit Duct for Proteins and Drugs.If, and when, a bacteria does become resistant to a phage, it is much easier and faster to find a new bacteriophage than it is to develop a new antibiotic.These two processes for the fixing of carbon into usable molecules (such as glucose) and stable calcareous molecules are large contributors to the global carbon cycle.It is thought that the tunnel assembly is supported by hydrogen bonds and salt bridges.TolC is interesting because unlike other efflux pumps, TolC bypasses the periplasm.This name is given because of its resemblance to elk antlers, in both shape and the brown color given by the photosynthetic protozoans living symbiotically inside the corals tissue.Fortunately, modern technology has had more success with phages than the discoverers.At least one of the strains causing the infection (PDR60) can be traced back to human sewage.This protein interacts with the inner membrane translocases traffic ATPase and an adaptor protein.In 2005 it was added to the endangered species list and remains there today despite many efforts to restore and revive the population.In review, the trimer forms a single beta barrel for the passing of proteins.(5)While phage therapy is not a new technique, it has only recently started a comeback as a viable antibacterial treatment.Once a phage is isolated, it could potentially be used to treat infected coral.[1] "What Is Phage Therapy?"A review of the mechanisms that drive Serratia towards diverse lifestyles.Modern knowledge of bacteriophages gives hope that phage therapy will not only work with but surpass antibiotic treatment.Bacteriophages are viruses that target bacteria to reproduce.
_source.human_practice: The students finished out the day with a snack and spent some time polishing up their presentations.We made it to day four of the camp and the students seemed as engrossed as they did on day one!The responses to this survey statement showed an initial preference towards disagreeing with the statement that Genetic Engineering is Unethical with some students indicating a lack of opinion on the topic due to the 20% of I dont Know responses.After the camp and our rigorous educational efforts on the uses for and importance of, genetically modified organisms in the medical field, the students reflected those efforts with strong indications towards agreement that GMOs should be used as vital medical treatment options.After completion of the camp, the students indicated a shift in opinion on the statement You are Familiar with GMOs towards agreement with the survey statement, providing evidence that over the course of the camp we presented information in such a way as to admirably educate on the topic of Genetic Modification.Harrison, Elise, and Jack presenting at Biotech Info NightIn late September, we held an informational night for the students on our campus.Throughout the week, the students learned various concepts on bioengineering, and they also spent quality time in the lab completing hands-on procedures.It is humbling to see that no one did not know whether genetic engineering is ethical or not; they all had an opinion in the matter.In our forty-five minute discussion with these students, most of them were able to formulate a better perception of how GMOs work and how they are applied to our world.It was interesting to see that this particular answer in the survey did not change significantly.Before commencement of the camp, the students showed a general lack of knowledge and disagreement with the topic of familiarity with GMOs.After the camp completed, there were no responses indicating a lack of opinion, with all students showing disagreement with the question, providing confidence in the education provided throughout the week.After completion of the camp, the students showed a strong opinion on the statement presented, with all students indicating that they believed Genetically Modified Organisms were not inherently dangerous to human health.The last lab of the week, the students spent time examining living coral samples, invertebrates, and bacteria, among other microorganisms under various microscopes.Following the presentation, we had multiple students approach us and ask how they could get involved with the WLC iGEM team.Lastly, towards the end of the day, the students went to work on their group projects, preparing to present on and share past iGEM projects with each other.Overall, the post-camp surveys indicated that the students greatly enjoyed the camp, learned a lot, and would love to return for an advanced, or altered summer camp in future years!The students were asked to agree or disagree with the statements on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).After the presentation at Biotech Info Night, there seems to be more students who disagree that GMOs are dangerous to human health.The students were asked to agree or disagree with the statements on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).The camp finished off with a fun jeopardy style bioengineering game that the students seemed to enjoy immensely.During the summer, the 2016 WLC iGEM held a week-long bioengineering summer camp for high school students.In the lab, Dr. Henkel led the students through plating and culturing of microorganisms from an external source point, specifically, raw eggs, chicken, and beef.This shows that our presentation was successful in informing the students on various concepts of biotechnology.As a result of biotechnology info night, there seemed to be an increase in the knowledge and opinions formed by the students who attended.This was the perfect way to set the tone for the rest of our summer camp as we deal with not only basic biology, but also some controversial topics.We then dove headfirst into science, first with the Central Dogma of Biology prepared by Dr. Werner.We did not have much time to cover all the topics involved with biotechnology, but we were able to get the ideas into the students minds.There is less variation in the students answers.Following our discourse and our discussion on ethics, the students seemed more likely to disagree with the fact that these matters are unethical.The day wrapped up with the students putting the final touches on their presentations for Friday morning.Friday began with the last devotion of the week and quickly moved into the students presentations on past iGEM projects.In lab, after lunch, Harrison led the students through an integrated lab where the students performed PCR, Gel Electrophoresis, and a Restriction Digest.This project was a chance for them to see what iGEM was all about and hopefully get them more interested in joining an iGEM team when they get to college.Today was a very exciting and enjoyable day for the campers!The following graphs are the result of the surveys which allow for analysis on how successful our camp was for our students.Over the course of the camp, we sought to incorporate and discuss bacteriophages in great detail as they play an integral part in our current project.Most of these students have attended Christian schools all of their lives; therefore, a short conversation on the matter will not sway their minds.The students showed a very strong initial lack of knowledge on the issue of use of Genetic ally Modified Organisms for Medical Treatments.This graph is strongly indicative of the general lack of information in the community on Bacteriophages and their uses as shown by the large percent (80%) of responses that were in strong disagreement with the statement or selected I dont Know.Students were able to learn about the structure of DNA and how it becomes RNA with licorice and marshmallows.The pre-camp and post-camp responses to the statement GMOs are inherently dangerous to Human Health indicate an initial lack of knowledge on this topic due to the large volume (40%) of I dont know responses.This is great for the continuation of the 2017 iGEM team and we have begun to involve new members into our project.Gina first shared the principles of water with magnetic models so the students could understand the difference between hydrogen, ionic, and covalent bonding.However, it is encouraging to see how many students disagree with the statement.There was an almost unanimous vote in the post-survey among the students.Dr. Henkel had the students plate the prepared samples on selective plates in order to incorporate bacterial identification into the lab and introduce the concept of gram negativity and gram positivity among other differences used in bacterial identification.It was the students turn to make bacteria glow red, and we used the plasmids they had isolated on Monday in the mini prep to do so.At the end of the day, we introduced the campers to the group project that they would be completing.The small scale science that we are performing in the lab this week really came to life.After the camp, the surveys showed a drastic split in survey response with a large number being in agreement and a large number being in strong disagreement.We advertised this event by passing out flyers at the tutoring center and asking professors of biology and chemistry to pass along the information to their students.Elise, Jack, and Harrison spoke to the eager undergraduates and they were also given a chance to ask questions of their own.The presentations went exceptionally well and although initially intimidated by the prospect of presenting for the class, the students excelled in their explanations of complicated genetic concepts and projects.After the student presentations, Dr. Balza presented on Coral biology and Morphology, helping further incorporate this years project into the camp along with touring the schools coral reproduction systems and marine life support equipment.We had the undergraduates participate in a survey before the presentation and also after the presentation.The central placement of the responses was expected due to our measured and cautious approach in discussion of this issue and the rising issue of antibiotic resistance.We discussed the various applications of biotechnology along with the implications of our own project on coral and bacteriophages.After lunch we headed into the lab.We started the day with a devotion and light snack, progressing quickly into what turned out to be one of the campers favorite lectures; Biological safety and Warfare with Dr. Henkel.Back at Wisconsin Lutheran College, Dr. Werner walked us through the basics of genetic engineering before we went into the lab once again.The responses received pre-camp to this question showed a large information gap in antibiotic education received prior to camp attendance with a majority of students simply responding with a selection of I dont Know.We began with some review from the day before with a fun jeopardy game.Dr. Henkel took over for the rest of the day and began with the importance of medical microbes.
_source.notebook: We ended the meeting with an icebreaker and organizing team leads for each portion of our project; with lab work planned to begin next week.Lab activities this week consisted of the plasmid isolation of the tolC gene on pUC57 for Salmonella enteric, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Escherichia coli, and Vibrio cholera in order to move to iGEM shipping plasmid pSB1C3.K. pneumonia, and E. coli which was largely worked on by Harrison and Melissa (the first trial had proven unsuccessful because of low DNA concentration).Jack contacted the various speakers for the camp and finalized the times that they would lecture.In the lab a gel electrophoresis protocol was performed by Harrison which determined that the second enzyme digest with the four tolC genes was unsuccessful.We also advertised the Bioengineering Summer Camp on our Facebook page.After a brief break in lab activities, work resumed by looking for bacteriophages that would bind to the TolC protein for S. marcescens.Meanwhile, Elise verified that many of the tolC genes were moved successfully into pTrc99A.The E. coli tolC gene from the previous week was extracted from the gel and a ligation to the pSB1C3 vector was attempted but was unsuccessful.Unfortunately, lab progressed fairly slowly due to our staff dedicating a majority of their time to the summer camp, but no regrets, as our students had a wonderful time.This was the highly anticipated week of the Bioengineering Summer Camp!We transformed these new plasmids into the tolC deletion strain of E. coli.The Biotech Info Night took place this week and Elise, Harrison, and Jack spoke to the 44 students in attendance.A new plasmid isolation was performed with the above tolC genes by Ching Tzu and Theresa Boyadjian with just the tolC genes for K. pneumonia and E. coli.Lab consisted of an enzyme digest using the products of the plasmid isolation from the previous week which was conducted by Harrison and Ching Tzu.The binders were filled with the PowerPoints of all of our lecturers and the lab was stocked with all the materials that would be needed.Summer Camp week!Gel electrophoresis by Harrison confirmed that the E. coli tolC gene was successfully removed from the plasmid.We really wanted to get as much of our wiki completed before Wiki Night to avoid the stress that comes from doing everything at the last minute.Elise and Ching-Tzu performed Western blots to verify our tolC gene expression on both plasmids.The campus cafeteria was also contacted to request lunch boxes for the campers during the day.We held our first meeting this week to get to know one another and to get an idea on the interests of our fellow teammates.The team also decided that we would be holding another Biotechnology Information Night on campus to better educate the new freshman on the various concepts.Additionally, we verified that all of the tolC genes had been successfully moved into the pTrc99A plasmid.We were prepared to welcome our students for a week of bioengineering fun!The week before summer camp was quite hectic.The school cafeteria was also informed on the number of campers and any concern of food allergies.This week was really focused on making sure that everything was prepared for the summer camp.Campers were asked to take the same survey before and after the summer camp to gauge the impact that our camp had on them.Overnight campers began to arrive on Sunday night and the rest of our campers joined us on Monday morning for a jam packed week.We set up a poster to give the new students a better idea of what iGEM really is.This was the first week back to school and the first time that the entire team was able to be together at once.In lab, Elise and Ching-Tzu verified that we successfully moved our three new BioBrick parts into the shipping plasmid!Committees were organized to help make things run more smoothly.The new part that was ordered arrived this week: the tolC gene for Serratia marcescens on pUC57 with the pBAD promoter.This week our wiki design was finalized and various parts of the project were sent to Troy to get uploaded onto our wiki.Additionally, Elise worked on Kirby Bauer assays with the strains that contained tolC genes on pTrc99A.Thursday night was our first meeting and we decided that there would be weekly meetings from now until the Giant Jamboree.Ligation of the E. coli tolC to pSB1C3 followed.Our project was solidified and plans began to form.We needed to put all the survey answers into bar graphs or pie charts.We started the design for our wiki.We also received survey responses from the WELS teachers which were then arranged onto pie charts to be analyzed.New freshman students were welcomed to campus this week.Jack and Harrison set up a table at the campus Org Smorg to recruit for the iGEM team for the following year.We created lectures on viruses/phages and antibiotics.The t-shirt design for the summer camp was agreed upon with the entire team and were then ordered.Kirby Bauer Assays were done a final time with the strains containing all of the tolC genes on pTrc99A .More phage screening was done to attempt to isolate phages.Jack contacted MSOE to guarantee their involvement with the Bioengineering Summer Camp.Another round of camp flyers were sent out to WELS churches.The team discussed the easiest and most efficient ways that this could be advertised throughout campus.Elise and Ching-Tzu started again working on moving our BioBricks into the shipping plasmid.Thus beginning our lab activities for the year as a continuation of last year s project.After this, Harrison ran a gel of the restriction digests and a gel extraction.Restriction enzyme digest followed to remove the part from the plasmid.Read about the blast that we had with our students here.
_source.result: To avoid using any pathogenic strains in lab, we used the tolC genes of the various bacteria in an E. coli deletion strain that lacks the gene.Lane 1 is the pTrc99A plasmid with no tolC gene, lane 2 is E. coli tolC in the pTrc99A plasmid, lane 3 is Klebsiella tolC in the pTrc99A plasmid and lane 4 is Serratia tolC in the pTrc99A plasmid.Figure 2: Western blot Analysis of TolC Protein Production by Plasmid-Encoded tolC Genes on pUC57.The top right plate is our positive control, as it contains the pTrc99A plasmid with the E. coli tolC gene.Once the TolC proteins were confirmed to be produced and functional in the tolC deletion strain of E. coli, we used these strains to screen for bacteriophages.The bottom left plates contain Serratia marcescens and Klebsiella pneumonia tolC genes on the pTrc99A plasmid respectively.Figure 4: Functional Variation in Pathogenic Bacterial TolC Proteins.Western blot analysis of the various strains containing plasmid encoded, pathogenic tolC genes demonstrate the production of the TolC protein (Figures 1 and 2).Alternatively, the genes can be expressed in pTrc99A, a medium copy number plasmid (Gel 1).Because TolC is necessary for antibiotic efflux, the presence of the protein in the outer-membrane increases antibiotic resistance.The Serratia tolC gene allows us to isolate bacteriophages specific to the Serratia TolC protein, which has potential for use in bacteriophage therapy of Elkorn coral, a highly endangered coral.However, our team plans to continue phage screening with these strains, especially the S. marcescens tolC strain: the goal being isolation of a TolC-specific phage that could be used in coral rehabilitation.After cloning the tolC genes into pTrC99A, we transformed the plasmids into a deletion strain of E. coli lacking the chromosomal tolC gene.This is likely because these tolC gene sequences are dramatically different than the E. coli tolC gene.The plasmid-encoded TolC proteins being produced in each strain are decreasing the minimum inhibitory zones (when compared to the strain containing only the plasmid).Previously, the purpose was to isolate bacteriophages that use TolC (an outer membrane protein) of pathogenic bacteria for infection.Reducing the copy number allowed better study of the function of TolC without the overproduction that occurs in a high copy number plasmid.These preliminary results do not show the induction we would expect, however, the protein is being produced.Figure 3: Functional Analysis of TolC Proteins.It is relevant to note that all of these bacteria, including E. coli normally contain the tolC gene, and therefore this gene modification will not result in increasing the pathogenicity of E. coli or causing this laboratory strain to be infectious in any way for humans.Each of the four plates was overlaid with top agar and a culture of E. coli that is lacking the chromosomal tolC gene.The average zones of inhibition in millimeters of multiple trials of Kirby-Bauer Antibiotic assays with standard deviation for both novobiocin and erythromycin is shown for each plasmid-encoded tolC gene.Various pathogenic tolC genes do not all work alike in E. coli.The top left plate demonstrates our negative control as it contains the pTrc99A plasmid with no tolC gene.We also added a new tolC gene, S. marcescens tolC, to our set of tolC genes of pathogenic bacteria.In the Kirby Bauer assays, the zones of inhibition, highlighted with a double headed arrow, demonstrate the minimum inhibitory concentration the antibiotics for each strain (Figure 3).Notably, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Vibrio cholera tolC genes do not appear to function in E. coli.Figure 1:Western blot Analysis of TolC Protein Production by Plasmid-Encoded tolC Genes on pTrc99A.Kirby-Bauer Antibiotic assays can be used to demonstrate functional TolC proteins.Notably, the production can be induced with arabinose when the plasmid with arabinose-inducible promoter is used (Gel 2).We first decided to move the tolC genes of pathogenic bacteria, namely: Escheria coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Proteus mirabilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Salmonella spp.

_source.description: We aim to enhance Mer Operon expression, improving previous synthetic genetic circuits and allying them with the construction of a bioreactor for water contaminated by mercury.We built the first (real) bioreactor to treat mercury contaminated water using our chassis carrying synthetic genetic circuits we developed!In this project we used the most abundant cell membrane protein in E. coli, the outer membrane A (OmpA) fused to a synthetic phytochelatin codon optimized by our team in order to bio-accumulate mercury.In the case of mercury, this complex structure is regulated by MerR repressor protein which binds to mer operator overlapped to its bidirectional promoter, having a weak expression.To apply this impressive mechanism in SynBio engineering systems is important to build new strong and well regulated genetic circuits to deeply understand its molecular interactions and to increase and improve its expression.With rivers pollution by mercury, near and inside Manaus, wild bacteria have acquired resistance to this metal.We achieved the ultimate proof of concept and it was the first step to have this synbio system working out there in the real world.With our genetic construction we achieved more than 97% of mercury bioremediation in 10 hours and then we made available diverse novel Biobricks for genetic constructions related to bioremediation.We isolated and identified mercury resistent bacteria from our rivers.This collection is well validated with RFP measurement and the most promising ones characterized with mercury chloride.Identifying an microorganism never isolated before in Amazonia and sequenced the first Amazon genome in this competition!We constructed the first library of new promoters regulated by MerR!
_source.human_practice: Paying attention to this, our team addresses the question of mercury contamination in the region we live, the Amazon, and embarked on the legal world to use the law in favor of environment and synbio!With the purpose of teaching Synthetic Biology in schools, our team desconstructed the current traditional model of brazilian schools education, bringing fresh and interactive subjects, pratical, playful and accessible activites to many classes of students who enjoyed our work.We developed an epic story about Bactie, our hero, genetically modified by brazilian scientists, and her fight against Merco, the evil Mercury, responsible for poisoning Amazon rivers.Plus we could disseminate our job, spreading our message about the problem of Mercury in Amazon and how we could solve this case throughout Synthetic Biology.In the Amazon, natural resources are frequently used in a wrong way, causing damages like environmental pollution.In this region of Brazil fish is the basic source of protein in the diet.Kids have this amazing talent to describe the entire world in a unique and creative way, based on what they see, feel and hear.Likewise, in the Universities we came with a better reasoned concept of the last scientific advances.In 2016, this barrier could not stay in our way.Recent researches show there are indigenous people with 92% (ninety two percent) of their individuals contaminated with heavy metal that comes mostly from the water they drink and from the fishes they eat.

_source.attribution: Tecnológico de Monterrey: Our institution, Tecnológico de Monterrey, located in Monterrey, Nuevo León, was founded in 1943 by Eugenio Garza Sada and a group of businessmen who formed a civil-and-nonprofit partnership, named "Higher Education and Research, A.C." Based in Monterrey, Mexico, the Institute has 31 campuses in 25 cities throughout the countryland, and is known as the first university ever connected to the Internet in Latin America, having one of the top graduate business schools in the region and being one of the leaders in patent applications among Mexican universities.Last, but never least, we want to thank our sponsors who helped us in _source.description: For example, one ton of e-waste from PCs contains more gold than the one recovered from 17 tons of gold ore [1].For these reasons we decided to make a project based on a eco-friendly bioleaching technology using two modified bacteria, Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans and Chromobacterium violaceum, for recovering metals from the e-waste.Bioleaching is the process of metal extraction undertaken by microorganisms.We will also test it as a potential selectivity marker for C. violaceum under these alkaline conditions (pH=9.5).After gold is recovered in the third module, we will degrade the remaining cyanide, as it is too toxic to be released to the environment without previous treatment.We will use a different transformant of C. violaceum that will overexpress cyanide hydratase, a cyanide degrading enzyme.It was found that the pH of the original strain had come down to a pH of 0.63, thus all organic material was dissolved despite A. ferrooxidans being an acidophile.With the acid oxidation process used in Module I, metals such as copper, zinc and nickel are solubilized by A. ferrooxidans, but valuable metals like gold and silver are not.(see Modelling)It was transformed successfully with a pretty standard electroporation protocol (Broetto et al, 2005).We were able to transform it using iGEMs standard PSB1C3 plasmid with a calcium competency protocol for E. coliIn order to improve the efficiency of the process, we will modify C. violaceum using two basic constructs:Though C. violaceum is a native cyanide producer, this basal production is relatively low and regulated by quorum sensing.In a previous study, cyanide production was successfully uncoupled from quorum sensing regulation by transformation with hydrogen cyanide _source.human_practice: Later CVR agreed to provide us with the shredded e-waste for our project.After this, we involved our community in different events aimed to create consciousness about e-waste pollution and the dreadful consequences of incorrect e-waste disposal.Meeting with CVR, one of the few certified e-waste recycling companies in Mexico.This aspect is reflected in our numerous events, evidence we saw on the enormous pile of e-waste we collected during four days, weighing almost a ton!We knew that informing our community about the issues we face every day and how synthetic biology is a powerful tool able to fix them wouldnt be enough.We also wanted to inform as much people as we could about the different ways in which they could participate and come up with solutions to help us improve our current situation.We sent this huge amount of e-waste to CVR, a certified recycling company, where it could be treated correctly.Throughout this process, our experience allowed us to evaluate and reshape our project according to societys needs.

_source.protocol: Transformation of Electro-Competent Cells  Escherichia coli Autoclave LB liquid media (500 µL per transformation) and LB-agar media (one control per antibiotic).Keep a 1.7 ml centrifuge tube (previously incubated for 15 minutes at -20ºC) and a 2 mm cuvette on ice at all time.Take 1 ?l of DNA (ligation or plasmid) and gently mix with 50 ?l of electrocompetent cells in the the cold 1.7 ml microcentrifuge tube.Pulse at 3000V (or 2500 if desired) 25 ?F 200 ohms.Transfer all volume to a 15 ml centrifuge tube and incubate 1 hour at 37oC 250Incubate 2 plates of LB + antibiotic of interest, at 37ºC 20 minutes before electroporated cells incubation time ends.Take 50 ?l of electroporated cells and plate them in one of the LB plates.Take 100 ?l of electroporated cells and plate them also on the other plate.Seidman, C. E., Struhl, K., Sheen, J., & Jessen, T. (2005).Expression and Purification of Proteins Preparation and Management of Reagents of Speciality Add 20 g of LB and 15 g of Agar to 1 L of distilled water.Measure the desired amount of antibiotic for making a stock solution and add to ethanol or distilled water.Ampicillin = 100 mg/ml stock solution in 50 ml half volume of water and half volume of 100% ethanol.Keep solution I and III at 4ºC and solution II at room temperature.Protocol 1.2 Calcium Competent Cells  Chromobacterium violaceum Autoclave 200mL of LB media placed in a 1L flask, glycerol, 4 centrifuge tubes, microcentrifuge tubes and 1L of 100 mM CaCl 2 .Inoculate a 20mL starter culture of LB (no antibiotics).Current protocols in molecular biology, 1-8.Protocol 1.1 Calcium Competent Cells  Escherichia coli Autoclave 200mL of LB media placed in a 1L flask, glycerol, 4 centrifuge tubes, microcentrifuge tubes and 1L of 100 mM CaCl 2 .Inoculate a 20mL starter culture of LB (no antibiotics).Heat shock each transformation tube by placing the bottom of the tube into a 42°C water bath for 60 seconds (time varies depending on the competent cells you are using).Add 500?l LB media (without antibiotic) and grow in 37°C shaking incubator for 1 hour.Plate 100 ?l of the transformation onto a 10cm LB agar plate containing the appropriate antibiotic.Seidman, C. E., Struhl, K., Sheen, J., & Jessen, T. (2005).Discard flow-through and place the QIAquick column back into the same tube.Centrifuge the QIAquick column in the provided 2 ml collection tube for 1 min to remove residual wash buffer.Place QIAquick column into a clean 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube.To elute DNA, add 20 ?l water to the center of the QIAquick membrane and centrifuge the column for 1 min.Measure the OD600 to make sure it is around 0.1.Grow in 37°C shaker for around 1.5 to 2 hours until OD600 reaches 0.4-0.6.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in one volume of ice cold dH2O.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in one volume of ice cold dH2O with 10% glycerol.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in half volume of ice cold dH2O with 10% glycerol.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in 300 times concentrate of ice cold dH2O with 10% glycerol.Aliquot 50?L into sterile 1.5 mL microfuge tubes and store at -80°C freezer.Seidman, C. E., Struhl, K., Sheen, J., & Jessen, T. (2005).Harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 5 minutes at 4°C.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in half volume of ice cold CaCl2.Put the cells on ice and chill the culture for 20 minutes.Harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 5 minutes at 4°C.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in half volume of ice cold CaCl2.Put the cells on ice and chill the culture for 15 minutes.Harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 5 minutes at 4°C.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend the pellet of one of the tubes in 500?L of ice cold CaCl2 and 20% of glycerol.Harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 5 minutes at 4°C.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in half volume of ice cold CaCl2.Put the cells on ice and chill the culture for 20 minutes.Harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 5 minutes at 4°C.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend each pellet in half volume of ice cold CaCl2.Put the cells on ice and chill the culture for 15 minutes.Harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 5 minutes at 4°C.Decant the supernatant and gently resuspend the pellet of one of the tubes in 500?L of ice cold CaCl2 and 20% of glycerol.Vortex the tube every 23 min to help dissolve gel.Add 1 gel volume isopropanol to the sample and mix.Place a QIAquick spin column in a provided 2 ml collection and apply the sample to the QIAquick column and centrifuge for 1 min.Change medium and add again antibiotic and make induction by adding IPTG in order to be diluted to between 0.1 mM to 1 mM.Change medium and add again antibiotic and make induction by adding IPTG in order to be diluted to between 0.1 mM to 1 mM.Grow in 30°C shaker at 100 rpm for around 3 to 4 hours.Transfer into sterile centrifuge tubes and harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 10 minutes at 4°C.Make sonification while having the tubes in ice for 3 min (10 seconds of sonification and 10 seconds of waiting).Centrifuge tubes and harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 10 minutes at 4°C.Current protocols in molecular biology, 1-8.Prepare starter culture cells by inoculating a 15mL starter culture of LB with the cells that have the desired plasmid (with the appropriate antibiotic).Prepare a flask of 500 mL with 200 mL of LB medium.Inoculate 100 mL of LB media with antibiotic and with starter culture and measure the OD600 to make sure it is around 0.1Grow in 37°C shaker at 250 rpm for around 1.5 to 2 hours until OD600 reaches 0.4-0.6.3.Grow culture at 37°C in shaker overnightDecant the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in about 1mL of LB mediaTransfer the supernatant to a new tube (around 500uL).Incubate at -20°C for 10 min (can be from 10 min to 2 hours).Qiagen.Our most typical reaction was set up to be 20 µL.Set up the reaction in a microcentrifuge tube on ice.Gently mix the reaction by pipetting up and down and microfuge briefly.Chill on ice and transform 1-5 ?l of the reaction into 50 ?l competent cells.Ligation Protocol with T4 DNA Ligase.Current protocols in molecular biology, 1-8.Measure the DNA concentration of the sample using the Nanodrop.Calculate the required concentrations of the components depending on the DNA of the sample, and the reaction volume.Ideally you must put 1 enzyme unit per each µg of DNA, yet the provider recommends using 10 times that quantity and adjust the volumes.Electro-Competent Cells  Chromobacterium violaceum Autoclave LB media placed in a 1L flask, glycerol, centrifuge tubes, microcentrifuge tubes and sterile dH2O.https://www.qiagen.com/us/shop/sample-technologies/dna/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/#orderinginformationMeasure the DNA concentration of the sample using the Nanodrop.Calculate the required concentrations of the components depending on the DNA of the sample, and the reaction volume.Ideally you must put 1 enzyme unit per each µg of DNA, yet the provider recommends using 10 times that quantity and adjust the volumes.The maximum amount of gel per spin column is 400 mg. For >2% agarose gels, add 6 volumes Buffer QG.Incubate at 50°C for 10 min (or until the gel slice has completely dissolved).Be careful with the bubbles and breaking the gel with the pipette.Fill the chamber with TAE and run the gel 70 min at 90 V and ~180 mAStain the gel soaking it in EtBr, be careful not to break it.Reveal using the transiluminator, first focus using the white light lamp and use the UV to make the bands visible.Excise the DNA fragment from the agarose gel with a clean, sharp scalpel.Weigh the gel slice in a colorless tube.Discard flow-through and place the QIAquick column back into the same tube.To wash, add 750 ?l Buffer PE to QIAquick column, let the column stand 25 min after addition of Buffer PE and centrifuge for 1 min.Transformation of Calcium Competent Cells Mix 1 to 5?l of DNA (usually 10pg to 100ng) into 50?L of competent cells in a microcentrifuge tube.Place the competent cell/DNA mixture on ice for 20min.Immediately divide the culture in sterile centrifuge tubes (about 40 mL) in each tube and put them on ice.Immediately divide the culture in sterile centrifuge tubes (about 40 mL) in each tube and put them on ice.Preparation and Management of Reagents of Speciality  Protocol 1.1 Calcium Competent Cells  Escherichia coli  Protocol 1.2 Calcium Competent Cells  Chromobacterium violaceum  Protocol 2.For increased DNA concentration, let the column stand for 5 min, and then centrifuge for 1 min.QIAquick Gel Extraction Kit.Grow culture at 37°C in shaker overnight.Inoculate 200mL of LB media with approximately 10mL starter culture.Grow culture at 37°C in shaker overnight.Inoculate 200mL of LB media with approximately 10mL starter culture.Grow culture at 37°C in shaker overnight.Inoculate 200mL of LB media with approximately 10mL starter culture.
_source.result: We found no previous report in the literature of the use of pSB1C3 in C. violaceum, so we proved that it can indeed be used in this new chassis, with the advantages of introducing a new chassis to iGEM that can be transformed using the standard plasmid.Characterization of BBa_R0010 in Chromobacterium violaceumWe characterized the promoter BBa_R0010 in a novel chassis, C. violaceum.We measured the composition of the slag with the technique Atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS), Juan José Cortés helped us with the procedure and we obtained these results.The weight of the dry slag after the digestion was 0.327 grams, therefore, the total grams of metal per gram of slag must be of 0.673, there are 0.0219 grams of metals left to calculate the composition so we asked Julio Rivera to conduct an ICP-OES to calculate them and we obtained these results.Therefore for our model, we know what is the maximum solubilization of metals.Heat shock transformation of Chromobacterium violaceum with the RFP-generator (BBa_J04450)We successfully transformed a novel chassis, Chromobacterium violaceum.There were no significant difference in the fluorescence of the between the induced and uninduced groups of C. violaceum, whereas in E. coli it showed normal induction and a clear difference of RFP expression when the inductor was added to the bacteria.We also showed that the part BBa_J04450 can be used as a reporter gene in a novel chassis, Chromobacterium violaceum.This part is a proton pump generator that is regulated by a weak constitutive promoter from the Anderson collection.However, in previous experiments we noticed that one of these two constructs actually reduced the viability of the bacteria, thus we determined it was not a reliable control group for our experiment.We adapted standardized E. coli protocols for calcium competency and heat shock transformation, successfully transforming C. violaceum.As seen in the figure, we tried preparing the calcium competent cells at different optical densities and transformed using different durations of heat shock.We transformed BL21 E. coli with three different constructs, one coding for the proton pump, and, as control groups, two constructs that consisted of the same plasmid as our proton pump (pUC-IDT, which has ampicillin resistance), but without the actual coding sequence for the proton pump.CueR is a transcription factor that stimulates the transcription at the pgolS promoter when bound to copper or gold, as was described by the iGEM York 2013.We calculated an average of the three replicates for each transformed strain and graphed the data in order to determine if the proton pump had a significant effect on the survivability of the bacteria.Thus, this construct increases its own expression through positive feedback in the presence of gold or copper through the production of a copper/gold sensitive protein.As the pgolS promoter has a basal transcription level, some CueR would be constantly expressed.Nevertheless, a basal activity for the fluorescence was found in the following graphWe used 2 different concentrations of copper as well as 4 different compositions of the shredded e-waste that CVR provided.Although transformation using an electroporation protocol had been described before, there was no previous report of a heat shock transformation of C. violaceum.The strain transformed with the proton pump had an exponential growth phase, while the others couldnt resist the alkaline pH and had minimal growth.Additionally, we used the RFP-generator (BBa_J04450) in pSB1C3 in the transformation.This modification to bacterial cell membrane may increase stress resistance under alkaline conditions.Characterization of the golS promoter in Chromobacterium violaceumWe submitted a new part: BBa_K2055369.Our conclusion is that the promoter BBa_R0010 can be used as a constitutive promoter in C. violaceum.BBa_R0010 is lacI regulated, however, we were unable to confirm whether or not C. violaceum produces lacI natively through a literature search, and BLAST analysis of its genome suggested that it does not have this regulating system.This was necessary because, as C. violaceum produces a native purple pigment (violacein), we were curious as to whether RFP would be useful as a reporter gene.In C.Violaceum, this part expressing the RFP, did not presented an inducible activity in the e-waste copper and gold compositions that Tec-Monterrey 2016 worked with.

_source.attribution: The main part of our project was finished by students from LANZHOU iGEM.Our wet lab work can be divided into three parts: Part construction, Part examination and Experiments on fish.Our work can be divided into 7 parts which are shown as follow.. Each part of work was finished by several team members.
_source.result: As shown in Figure 9, experimental groups fed with engineered E. coli BL21 containing IC had significantly lower mercury, close to the levels in Control 1.Figure 3: (A) Fluorescence spectra of IC (OD600 = 1.3), in the presence of Hg2+, at varying concentrations.There were black spots on the outer membrane of the engineered E. coli (Figure 8-B), but not on control E. coli BL21 cells (Figure 8-D).It could be seen that only Hg2+ and Cu2+ caused dramatic fluorescence quenching, and there were no obvious fluorescence changes for the other metal ions (Figure 4-A ).Bacteria with the surface-displayed GFP-MC are able to adsorb mercury ions up to 40 mg/g cells, which is 10-fold higher than control cells (Figure 7-A).As shown in Figure 7-B, the rates of effective adsorption of GFP-MC displayed cells in the mercury ions concentration of 12.5 mg/L ranged from 24.09% to 55.72%.Figure 8: (A)-(B) The TEM images of E. coli BL21/INP-GFP-MC cells.The addition of Hg2+ (100 ?M) induced a significant decline in the fluorescence emission of GFP-MC, which indicated that GFP-MC can be used as a sensor for Hg2+ detection.Furthermore, the addition of divalent sulfur (S2-) could completely restore the fluorescence of GFP-MC, implying that the interaction between GFP-MC and Hg2+ is reversible (Figure 3-C).Similarly, there is a similar result was obtained for ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (Figure 3-D).To examine the morphology of the mercury adsorbed on the GFP-MC-displayed cells, the engineered E. coli bacteria cells were incubated with 12.5 mg/l Hg2+ overnight.Additionally, Table 1 indicates that the presence of engineered E. coli did not interfere with fish growth.Illustration of the mercury-specific metal catcher displayed on E. coli cell surface via the Inp-N. (B) Standing for the adsorbed mercury ions.(B) The effective adsorption rate of Hg2+ by engineered E. coli.Additionally, the presence of engineered E. coli did not affect fish growth.To examine the specificity of the biosensor, the fluorescence responses of GFP-MC toward various metal ions, including Cd2+, Pb2+, Ba2+, Mo6+, Ni2+, Hg2+, Mn2+, Ca2+, Ag+, Zn2+, and Cu2+, were studied under the same conditions.After MC binding of Hg2+ on the surface, the fluorescence emission of GFP-MC is quenched.Figure 10: (A) Rarefaction analysis of the different fish.An energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy system was used to verify the cells and it verifies that the black spots were the MC accumulated Hg2+ (Figure 8-C).The results showed that the mercury ions were adsorbed on GFP-MC protein-displayed cells by surface display system.With the increase in the concentration of Hg2+ from 0 to 100 ?M, fluorescence of GFP-MC decreased continually.This strategy was adopted for targeting the GFP-MC to the surface of E. coli.(C) EDXA measurement of the box from (D) The control TEM images of E. coli BL21.Mercury content in the Control 1 fish decreased by 62.5% compared to Control 2.As shown in Figure 8 (A) the GFP-MC was on the cell surface and was approximately 500 nm in size.Ice nucleation protein (INP) is an extrinsic membrane protein; since the truncated version of INP only contains the N-terminal domain, which is the anchor membrane and GFP-MC, the fusion protein was displayed on the surface of E. coli, without any adverse effects on cell growth and integrity.Moreover, the coexistence of other metal ions showed no obvious interference in Hg2+ assays (Figure 4-B).The concentration of mercury in the fish of Control group 1 was 0.49 µg/g, while that in control group 2 was 1.664 µg/g and in the experimental group, it was 0.623 µg/g.Figure 4:(A) Selectivity of the IC sensing system.Figure 2: (A) Fluorescence images of engineering E. coli cells.A protein band of 43 kDa, corresponding to the correct size of INP-N-GFP-MC, was detected from cells containing recombinant plasmid (Figure 1, lane 7).The calibration curve of the concentration dependence of Cu2+ showed a good linear relationship (R2 = 0.9846) in the concentration ranging from 0 to 20 uM (Figure 5 A-B).An outer membrane protein INP-N was fused to the GFP-MC gene, creating an INP-GFP-MC which was designated _source.attribution: Our circuit is largely based off the following papers and groups:the work with toehold switches, cell-free systems, and paper-based sensors detailed in "Paper-Based Synthetic Gene Networks" by Pardee et al., which we consistently refer to as "the Collins paper"; the 2015 Pitt iGEM team and their work with cell-free, paper-based systems and the Collins materials;the thallium DNAzyme described by Huang, Vazin, and Liu in "Desulfurization Activated Phosphorothioate DNAzyme for the Detection of Thallium";the lead DNAzyme developed by Lan, Furuya, and Lu in "A highly selective lead sensor based on a classic lead DNAzyme";the amplification systems developed by Wang, Barahona, and Buck in "Engineering modular and tunable genetic amplifiers for scaling transcriptional signals in cascaded gene networks"; andtoehold switch design described by the 2015 Exeter iGEM team.Huge thank-you s go to the following groups and people for making this year s iGEM team a success:the Collins Lab at MIT for sending us their pT7 toehold structures;Dave Gau from the Roy Lab, who provided us with the various odds and ends we needed to grow cells;Steve from the Shroff Lab, who provided us with reagents and materials for making buffers, a freezer, and friendliness every day;Neill Turner from the McGowan Institute for giving us access to a plate reader;Nick Ankenbruck from the Deiters Lab, who helped us run polyacrylamide gels, andOur advisors and mentors met with us every week to discuss ideas for the circuit, experimental results, experimental design, and presentations.
_source.description: Our improved characterization of codon-optimized fluorescent proteins developed by the 2015 Carnegie Mellon team.We characterized the proteins as possible reporters for our system.However, we decided not to use fluorescent proteins since they cannot be seen with the naked eye unless they are in high concentration.Most proteins (except GFP and OFP) reached maximum fluorescence within 6 hours of growth.

_source.modeling: We decided to treat the blood and bones of a contaminated person as two different systems to more accurately model how the body metabolizes lead and processes it.Unfortunately, this means that the child will continue to have prolonged exposure to lead at a very low level.With all the important information put into the model, we were able to begin simulating lead exposure.To examine the effect of severity of exposure over the same period of time, we ran simulations of a 100 day exposure to different levels of contamination range including 25, 50, 75, and 100 ppb.The results of these simulations are below It s clear that while the blood lead levels spike quickly, the body is able to filter the lead out of its system within 3 or 4 months after the initial exposure.This model provides a quantified approach relating the level and duration of lead exposure with the concentration of lead in the blood.You should note that as the duration of exposure increases, so does the variation in blood lead level, meaning that the severity for the same level of contamination will be more of a range than one distinct value.The Effect of Lead Contamination in Drinking Water on a Young Population  In developing a lead sensor for our project, we were curious about the effects of lead contamination in the water supply on small children.We were pretty appalled by the devastating effects lead can have on the human body and how long it can persist even after the initial exposure.Whether it is in estimating the severity of the events in Flint, Michigan or in detecting the threshold of exposure without noticeable side effects, this model could be the first step in better realizing how our bodies take up, store and slowly get rid of lead.With these literature values, we were able to create a rudimentary mass balance of the human body focusing on the amount of lead ingested and the amount that is excreted.The results of these simulations are shown below  Here we can see that even though the increase in lead in the bones is linear with time, the concentration of lead in the blood appears to begin reaching a saturation point.We began with a thorough examination of the literature, looking for important details on how much lead is absorbed into the body, where the absorbed lead goes, and how long it stays in the body.To account for the different amounts of water a child may drink in a given day, we ran the simulation 50 times and plotted them all on the same graph.Blood-lead levels do reach different levels of saturation but now we see that the rate at which lead is absorbed by the bones increases with contamination severity.Initially, we used a pulse of lead contamination of 50 ppb for 10 days on a 1-year-old child.This gave us a range of possible blood lead level concentrations based off of the level of lead contamination as we will see later.Determining the blood volume was a little tricky.We decided to look at the same level of exposure (50 ppb) but for increasing intervals of time (ranging from the initial 10 days and increasing to 25, 50 and 100 days of exposure.To get a better look at just the blood concentrations, below is a zoomed-in portion of the same graph just focussing on blood-lead levels for the first 200 days.As of yet there is no hard evidence that proves such a long exposure to lead at a low level can do any damage, there is a growing notion that an exposure like this at such a young age can make the individual at higher risk for depression and other neurological conditions.This is not true for the bones because the lead that makes it into the bones stays around much longer.We were able to find the average water consumed by a child based on their age in order to get an idea of their lead intake.This was meant to simulate a brief exposure to a mild amount of lead.We decided to model it using a 500 day window to see the long-term effects of lead exposure.

_source.protocol: We use the 1 kb DNA ladder from NEB.Dissolve 0.5 g agarose in 50 mL 1X TAE buffer, using the microwave to heatWhen cool to the touch, add 5 µL ethidium bromide and pour gelWe follow the protocols provided by Thermo Scientific for their GeneJET Gel Extraction and DNA Cleanup0.5 µL rSAP (recombinant shrimp alkaline phosphatase)We follow the PCR protocol provided by NEB for Phusion High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase.We use the Colony PCR Protocol for plated colonies from the 2013 iGEM page.Gel Check: Run 2.5 µl of the reaction on a gel.We elute the DNA in 25 µL of Elution Buffer, not 50 µL as stated in the protocol, to achieve a higher concentration.We use Genewiz for sequencing and follow their sample submission guidelines.We use the protocol provided by Thermo Scientific for the fast digestion of DNA as a guide.All gels are 1% agarose unless otherwise stated.Any deviations from this protocol are noted in the Lab Notebook.Combine 1 mL of 40% glycerol with 1 mL fresh bacterial culture in a cryogenic vialWe follow the miniprep protocol provided by Thermo Scientific for their GeneJET Plasmid Miniprep Kit.The final oligo concentration is 1µM.Any deviations from this protocol from iGEM to determine our cells  competency.We follow the transformation protocol provided by iGEM.Adjust the volume with DI water until the volume is 1 LOligo final concentration is 10 uM.Incubate the PCR tube in the thermocycler with the program at 37°C for 60 minutes, then at 65°C for 20 minutes then end.Mix well and spin down.We followed the updated Plate Reader Protocol from iGEM.
_source.result: To our knowledge, we are the first to demonstrate that a DNA strand can also trigger a toehold switch.As shown in the results for the Hairpin versus Duplex experiment above, the duplex and folded hairpin do not activate the toehold switch because the trigger is hybridized to the catalytic strand.Results from sequencing in Week 11 suggest that our completed construct contains CFP instead of amilCP, although the construct contains both the pT7-RBS and terminator.The final concentration of DNAzyme in the reactions is 3.74 nM, and the final concentration of lead is 2 µM.As shown below with data from Week 5, the plasmid triggers activate the toehold switch with as little as 10 ng of plasmid in a 25-?L reaction.However, a comparison by concentration of DNA instead of mass would be more accurate because the plasmid has much more "extra" DNA than the linear form.In Week 6, we ran cell-free reactions over a range of volumes.However, the duplex did not activate the toehold switch.We started working with the lead hairpin DNAzyme in Week 13.In Week 6, we found that the DNA trigger also activated the toehold switch at concentrations as low as 1 pM.In cell-free extract, the lead hairpin DNAzyme produces higher activation of the toehold switch than the duplex DNAzyme in a 1:1000 ratio.Below, the LacZ expression produced by the toehold switch activated by the hairpin DNAzyme cleavage product is compared to the LacZ expression in a system without lead.This could be a result of the excess catalytic strand interfering with the other processes occurring in the reaction.Although the dPAGE assays we performed in Weeks 7 to 10 do not provide clear information, the cell-free reactions suggest that the DNAzyme does cleave its substrate.Since we do not have a LacZ we can use, we have not started construction of this second part of the amplifier.The time course data shown below is more a function of evaporation than reaction progress; the liquid evaporated over the course of the run.We analyzed the efficiency of sequestration in Week 11.As shown in the figure below, there was still a signal with a reaction volume of 5 ?L.In addition, the triggers are switch-specific--the trigger for the D switch does not activate the G switch.However, after leaving them in the incubator overnight, the reactions darkened in color.For more details about our daily activities and experiments, visit our Notebook.In Week 8, we found that linear DNA does not perform better than plasmid DNA in PURExpress.The gel below suggests that all of the substrate strand is sequestered, but the thickness of the catalytic strand s band as the ratio increases could be blocking the signal from the substrate strand.After six hours of incubation in the plate reader, the diluted reactions did not turn purple.The results of the main experiments described on the Experiments page.
_source.safety: We also learned how to act in cases of emergency.In Chemical Hygiene Training (slides here), we learned how to use safety reference materials.Representatives from the Environmental Health and Safety Department held training sessions about biological safety and chemical safety.In Bloodborne Pathogens Training (slides here), we learned about the hazards of bloodborne pathogens and infected materials.All students participated in the university s mandatory lab safety training sessions.The training also covered appropriate preventive measures, such as personal protective equipment and safe lab practices.
